& \psi \leftarrow \psi+l(j) \alpha_{\psi} \Delta \psi \\
& \phi \leftarrow \phi+l(j) \alpha_{\phi} \Delta \phi
\end{aligned}
$$

Update $k \leftarrow k+1$
end while
end for

# 5 Application: Mean-Variance Portfolio Selection 

We now present an applied example of the general theory and algorithms derived. Consider investing in a market where there are a risk-free asset and a risky asset (e.g. a stock or an index). The risk-free rate is given by a constant $r_{f}$ and the risky asset price process follows

$$
d S_{t}=S_{t-}\left[\mu d t+\sigma d W_{t}+\int_{\mathbb{R}}(\exp (z)-1) \widetilde{N}(d t, d z)\right]
$$

Let $X_{t}$ be the discounted wealth value at time $t$, and $a_{t}$ is the discounted dollar value of the investment in the risky asset. The self-financing discounted wealth process follows

$$
d X_{t}^{a}=a_{t} \sigma \rho d t+a_{t} \sigma d W_{t}+a_{t} \int_{\mathbb{R}}(\exp (z)-1) \widetilde{N}(d t, d z)
$$

where $\rho$ is the Sharpe ratio of the risky asset and given by

$$
\rho=\frac{\mu-r_{f}}{\sigma}
$$

We assume

$$
\int_{|z|>1} \exp (z) \nu(d z)<\infty, \quad \int_{|z|>1} \exp (2 z) \nu(d z)<\infty
$$

Condition (36) implies that $\mathbb{E}\left[S_{t}\right]$ and $\mathbb{E}\left[S_{t}^{2}\right]$ are finite for every $t \geq 0$; see (Cont and Tankov 2004, Proposition 3.14). We set

$$
\sigma_{J}^{2}:=\int_{\mathbb{R}}(\exp (z)-1)^{2} \nu(d z)
$$

which is finite by conditions (1) and (36).
Fix the investment horizon as $[0, T]$. The mean-variance (MV) portfolio selection problem considers

$$
\min _{a} \operatorname{Var}\left[X_{T}^{a}\right] \quad \text { subject to } \mathbb{E}\left[X_{T}^{a}\right]=z
$$

We seek the optimal pre-committed strategy for the MV problem as in Zhou and Li (2000). We can transform the above constrained problem into an unconstrained one by introducing a Lagrange multiplier, which yields

$$
\min _{a} \mathbb{E}\left[\left(X_{T}^{a}\right)^{2}\right]-z^{2}-2 \omega\left(\mathbb{E}\left[X_{T}^{a}\right]-z\right)=\min _{a} \mathbb{E}\left[\left(X_{T}^{a}-\omega\right)^{2}\right]-(\omega-z)^{2}
$$

Note that the optimal solution to the unconstrained minimization problem depends on $\omega$, and we can obtain the optimal multiplier $\omega^{*}$ by solving $\mathbb{E}\left[X_{T}^{a^{*}}(\omega)\right]=z$.

The exploratory formulation of the problem is

$$
\min _{\boldsymbol{\pi}} \mathbb{E}_{t, x}^{\tilde{\mathbb{P}}}\left[\left(X_{T}^{\boldsymbol{\pi}}-\omega\right)^{2}+\theta \int_{t}^{T} \log \boldsymbol{\pi}\left(a_{s}^{\boldsymbol{\pi}} \mid s, X_{s-}^{\boldsymbol{\pi}}\right) d s\right]-(\omega-z)^{2}
$$

where the discounted wealth under a stochastic policy $\boldsymbol{\pi}$ follows

$$
d X_{s}^{\boldsymbol{\pi}}=a_{s}^{\boldsymbol{\pi}} \sigma \rho d s+a_{s}^{\boldsymbol{\pi}} \sigma d W_{s}+a_{s}^{\boldsymbol{\pi}} \int_{\mathbb{R}}(\exp (z)-1) \widetilde{N}(d s, d z), \quad s \in[t, T], X_{s}^{\boldsymbol{\pi}}=x
$$

# 5.1 Solution of the exploratory control problem 

We consider the HJB equation for problem (38):

$$
\frac{\partial V}{\partial t}(t, x)+\inf _{\pi \in \mathcal{P}(\mathbb{R})} \int_{\mathbb{R}}\left\{H\left(t, x, a, V_{x}, V_{x x}, V\right)+\theta \log \pi(a \mid t, x)\right\} \pi(a \mid t, x) d a=0
$$

with the terminal condition $V(T, x)=(x-\omega)^{2}-(\omega-z)^{2}$. Note that supremum becomes infimum and the sign before $\theta \log \pi(a \mid t, x)$ flips compared with (24) because we consider minimization here. The Hamiltonian of the problem is given by

$$
\begin{aligned}
H\left(t, x, a, V_{x}, V_{x x}, V\right) & =a \sigma \rho V_{x}(t, x)+\frac{1}{2} a^{2} \sigma^{2} V_{x x}(t, x) \\
& +\int_{\mathbb{R}}(V(t, x+\gamma(a, z))-V(t, x)-\gamma(a, z) V_{x}(t, x)) \nu(d z)
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\gamma(a, z)=a\left(e^{z}-1\right)$. We take the following ansatz for the solution of the HJB equation (40):

$$
V(t, x)=(x-\omega)^{2} f(t)+g(t)-(\omega-z)^{2}
$$

As $V(t, x)$ is quadratic in $x$, we can easily calculate the integral term in the Hamiltonian and obtain

$$
H\left(t, x, a, V_{x}, V_{x x}, V\right)=a \sigma \rho V_{x}(t, x)+\frac{1}{2} a^{2}\left(\sigma^{2}+\sigma_{J}^{2}\right) V_{x x}(t, x)
$$

The probability density function that minimizes the integral in (40) is given by

$$
\pi_{c}(\cdot \mid t, x) \propto \exp \left(-\frac{1}{\theta} H\left(t, x, a, V_{x}, V_{x x}, V\right)\right)
$$

which is a candidate for the optimal stochastic policy. From (42), we obtain

$$
\pi_{c}(\cdot \mid t, x) \sim \mathcal{N}\left(\cdot \mid-\frac{\sigma \rho V_{x}}{\left(\sigma^{2}+\sigma_{J}^{2}\right) V_{x x}}, \frac{\theta}{\left(\sigma^{2}+\sigma_{J}^{2}\right) V_{x x}}\right)
$$

Substituting it back to the HJB equation (40), we obtain a nonlinear PDE as

$$
\begin{aligned}
& V_{t}-\frac{\rho^{2} \sigma^{2}}{2\left(\sigma^{2}+\sigma_{J}^{2}\right)} \frac{\left(V_{x}\right)^{2}}{V_{x x}}-\frac{\theta}{2} \ln \frac{2 \pi \theta}{\left(\sigma^{2}+\sigma_{J}^{2}\right) V_{x x}}=0, \quad(t, x) \in[0, T) \times \mathbb{R} \\
& V(T, x)=(x-\omega)^{2}-(\omega-z)^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

We plug in the ansatz (41) to the above PDE and obtain that $f(t)$ satisfies

$$
f^{\prime}(t)-\frac{\rho^{2} \sigma^{2}}{\sigma^{2}+\sigma_{J}^{2}} f(t)=0, f(T)=1
$$

and $g(t)$ satisfies

$$
g^{\prime}(t)-\frac{\theta}{2} \ln \frac{\pi \theta}{\left(\sigma^{2}+\sigma_{J}^{2}\right) f(t)}=0, g(T)=0
$$

These two ordinary differential equations can be solved analytically, and we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
V(t, x)= & (x-\omega)^{2} \exp \left(-\frac{\rho^{2} \sigma^{2}}{\sigma^{2}+\sigma_{J}^{2}}(T-t)\right)+\frac{\theta \rho^{2} \sigma^{2}}{4\left(\sigma^{2}+\sigma_{J}^{2}\right)}\left(T^{2}-t^{2}\right) \\
& -\frac{\theta}{2}\left(\frac{\rho^{2} \sigma^{2}}{\sigma^{2}+\sigma_{J}^{2}} T+\ln \frac{\pi \theta}{\sigma^{2}+\sigma_{J}^{2}}\right)(T-t)-(\omega-z)^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

It follows that

$$
\boldsymbol{\pi}_{c}(\cdot \mid t, x) \sim \mathcal{N}\left(\cdot \mid-\frac{\sigma \rho}{\sigma^{2}+\sigma_{J}^{2}}(x-\omega), \frac{\theta}{2\left(\sigma^{2}+\sigma_{J}^{2}\right)} \exp \left(\frac{\rho^{2} \sigma^{2}}{\sigma^{2}+\sigma_{J}^{2}}(T-t)\right)\right)
$$

It is straightforward to verify that $\boldsymbol{\pi}_{c}$ is admissible by checking the four conditions in Definition 1. Furthermore, $V$ solves the HJB equation (40) and shows quadratic growth. Therefore, by Lemma 5 , we have the following conclusion.

Proposition 2. For the unconstrained MV problem (37), the optimal value function $J^{*}(t, x)=$ $V(t, x)$ and the optimal stochastic policy $\boldsymbol{\pi}^{*}=\boldsymbol{\pi}_{c}$.

When there is no jump, we have $\sigma_{J}^{2}=0$ and thus recover the expressions of the optimal value function and optimal policy derived in Wang and Zhou (2020) for the unconstrained MV problem in the pure diffusion setting.

# 5.2 Parametrizations for $q$-learning 

It is important to observe that the optimal value function, optimal policy and the Hamiltonian given by (42) take the same structural forms regardless of the presence of jumps, while the only differences are the constant coefficients in those functions. However, those coefficients are unknown anyway and will be parameterized in the implementation of our RL algorithms. Consequently, we can use the same parameterizations for the optimal value function and optimal $q$-function for learning as in the diffusion setting of Jia and Zhou (2023). This important insight, concluded only after a rigorous theoretical analysis, shows that the continuous-time RL algorithms are robust to the presence of jumps and essentially model-free, at least for the MV portfolio selection problem.

Following Jia and Zhou (2023), we parametrize the value function as

$$
J^{\psi}(t, x ; \omega)=(x-\omega)^{2} e^{-\psi_{3}(T-t)}+\psi_{2}\left(t^{2}-T^{2}\right)+\psi_{1}(t-T)-(\omega-z)^{2}
$$

and the $q$-function as

$$
q^{\phi}(t, x, a ; w)=-\frac{e^{-\phi_{2}-\phi_{3}(T-t)}}{2}\left(a+\phi_{1}(x-w)\right)^{2}-\frac{\theta}{2}\left[\log 2 \pi \theta+\phi_{2}+\phi_{3}(T-t)\right]
$$

Let $\psi=\left(\psi_{1}, \psi_{2}, \psi_{3}\right)^{\top}$ and $\phi=\left(\phi_{1}, \phi_{2}, \phi_{3}\right)^{\top}$. The policy associated with the parametric $q$-function is $\boldsymbol{\pi}^{\phi}(\cdot \mid t, x ; w)=\mathcal{N}\left(-\phi_{1}(x-w), \theta e^{\phi_{2}+\phi_{3}(T-t)}\right)$. In addition to $\psi$ and $\phi$, we learn the Lagrange multiplier $\omega$ in the same way as in Jia and Zhou (2023) by the stochastic approximation algorithm that updates $\omega$ with a learning rate after a fixed number of iterations.

# 5.3 Simulation study 

We assess the effect of jumps on the convergence behavior of our algorithms via a simulation study. We use the same basic setting as in Jia and Zhou (2023): $x_{0}=1, z=1.4, T=1$ year, $\Delta t=1 / 252$ years (corresponding to one trading day), and a chosen temperature parameter $\theta=0.1$. We consider two market simulators: one is given by the Black-Scholes (BS) model and the other is Merton's jump-diffusion (MJD) model in which the Lévy density is a scaled Gaussian density, i.e.,

$$
\nu(z)=\lambda \frac{1}{\sqrt{2 \pi \delta^{2}}} \exp \left(-\frac{(z-m)^{2}}{2 \delta^{2}}\right), \lambda>0, \delta>0, m \in \mathbb{R}
$$

where $\lambda$ is the arrival rate of the Poisson jumps. The Gaussian assumption is a common choice in the finance literature for modeling the jump-size distribution (see e.g. Merton 1976, Bates 1991, Das 2002), partly due to its tractability for statistical estimation and partly because heavy-tailed distributions may not be easily identified from real data when the number of jumps is limited (see Heyde and Kou 2004).

Under the latter model, we have

$$
\sigma_{J}^{2}=\lambda\left[\exp \left(2 m+2 \delta^{2}\right)-2 \exp \left(m+\frac{1}{2} \delta^{2}\right)+1\right]
$$

To mimic the real market, we set the parameters of these two simulators by estimating them from the daily data of the S\&P 500 index using maximum likelihood estimation (MLE). Our estimation data cover a long period from the beginning of 2000 to the end of 2023. In Table 1, we summarize the estimated parameter values (used for the simulators) and the corresponding value of $\phi_{1}^{*}$ in the optimal policy. Note that although we use a stochastic policy to interact with the environment during training to update the policy parameters, for actual execution of portfolio selection we apply a deterministic policy which is the mean part of the optimal stochastic policy after it has been learned. So it is off-policy learning here. The advantage of doing so among others is to reduce the variance of the final wealth; see Huang et al. (2022) for a discussion on this approach. As a result, here we only display the values for $\phi_{1}^{*}$ in these two environments and use them as benchmarks to check the convergence of our algorithm (see Figure 1).

![table_0](table_0)

Table 1: Parameters used in the two simulators. The column "Optimal" reports the values of $\phi_{1}$ in the optimal policies calculated using the respective simulators.

For offline learning, the Lagrange multiplier $\omega$ is updated after every $m=10$ iterations, and the parameter vectors $\psi$ and $\phi$ are initialized as zero vectors. The learning rates are set to be $\alpha_{w}=0.05, \alpha_{\psi}=0.001$, and $\alpha_{\phi}=0.1$ with decay rate $l(j)=j^{-0.51}$, where $j$ is the iteration index. In each iteration, we generate 32 independent $T$-year trajectories to update the parameters. We train the model for $N=20000$ iterations.

We also consider online learning with $\Delta t$ equal to one trading day. We select a batch size of 128 trading days and update the parameters after this number of observations coming in. We

set $m=1$ for updating $\omega$ and initialize $\psi$ and $\phi$ as zero vectors. The learning rates are set as $\alpha_{w}=0.01, \alpha_{\psi}=0.001$, and $\alpha_{\phi}=0.05$ with decay rate $l(j)=j^{-0.51}$. Some of the rates are notably smaller under online learning because now we update with fewer observations and thus must be more cautious. The model is again trained for $N=20000$ iterations.

Figure 1 plots the convergence behavior of offline and online learning under both simulators or market environments (one with jumps and one without). The algorithms have converged after a sufficient number of iterations, whether jumps are present or not. This demonstrates that convergence of the offline and online $q$-learning algorithms proposed in Jia and Zhou (2023) under the diffusion setting is robust to the presence of jumps for mean-variance portfolio selection. However, jumps in the environment can introduce more variability in the convergence process as seen from the plots.

# 5.4 Effects of jumps 

The theoretical analysis so far in this section shows that, for the mean-variance problem, one does not need to know in advance whether or not the stock prices have jumps in order to carry out the RL task, because the optimal stochastic policy is Gaussian and the corresponding value function and $q$-function have the same structures for parameterization irrespective of the presence of jumps.

However, we stress that this is rather an exception than a rule. Here we give a counterexample.
Consider a modification of the mean-variance problem where the controlled system dynamics is

$$
d X_{t}^{a}=a_{t} \sigma \rho d t+a_{t} \sigma d B_{t}+\int_{\mathbb{R}} \gamma\left(a_{t}, z\right) \widetilde{N}(d t, d z)
$$

with

$$
\gamma(a, z)=a^{2}
$$

and the exploratory objective is

$$
J^{*}(t, x ; w)=\min _{\boldsymbol{\pi}} \mathbb{E}_{t, x}^{\mathbb{P}}\left[\left(X_{T}^{\boldsymbol{\pi}}-w\right)^{2}+\theta \int_{t}^{T} \log \boldsymbol{\pi}\left(a_{s}^{\boldsymbol{\pi}} \mid s, X_{s-}^{\boldsymbol{\pi}}\right) d s\right]-(\omega-z)^{2}
$$

Note that this is not a mean-variance portfolio selection problem because (45) does not correspond to a self-financed wealth equation with a reasonably modelled stock price process.

The Hamiltonian is given by

$$
\begin{aligned}
H\left(t, x, a, v_{x}, v_{x x}, v\right)= & a \sigma \rho v_{x}(t, x)+\frac{1}{2} a^{2} \sigma^{2} v_{x x}(t, x) \\
& +\int_{\mathbb{R}}\left(v\left(t, x+a^{2}\right)-v(t, x)-a^{2} \cdot v_{x}(t, x)\right) \nu(d z)
\end{aligned}
$$

If an optimal stochastic policy exists, then it must be

$$
\boldsymbol{\pi}^{*}(a \mid t, x) \propto \exp \left(-\frac{1}{\theta} H\left(t, x, a, J_{x}^{*}, J_{x x}^{*}, J^{*}\right)\right)
$$

We show by contradiction that the optimal stochastic policy can not be Gaussian in this case. Note that if there is no optimal stochastic policy, then it would already demonstrate that jumps matter because the optimal stochastic policy for the case of no jumps exists and is Gaussian.

Remark 4. The existence of optimal stochastic policy in (48) is equivalent to the integrability of the quantity $\exp \left(\frac{1}{\theta} H\left(t, x, a, J_{x}^{*}, J_{x x}^{*}, J^{*}\right)\right)$ over $a \in \mathcal{A}=(-\infty, \infty)$. This integrability depends on the tail behavior of the Hamiltonian and, in particular, the behavior of $J^{*}\left(t, x+a^{2}\right)$ when $a^{2}$ is large.

Suppose the optimal stochastic policy $\boldsymbol{\pi}^{*}(\cdot \mid t, x)$ is Gaussian for all $(t, x)$, implying that the Hamiltonian $H\left(t, x, a, J_{x}^{*}, J_{x x}^{*}, J^{*}\right)$ is a quadratic function of $a$. It then follows from (47) that there exist functions $h_{1}(t, x)$ and $h_{2}(t, x)$ such that

$$
J^{*}\left(t, x+a^{2}\right)-J^{*}(t, x)-a^{2} J_{x}^{*}(t, x)=a^{2} \cdot h_{1}(t, x)+a \cdot h_{2}(t, x), \quad \text { for all }(t, x, a)
$$

We do not put a term independent of $a$ on the right-hand side because the left-hand side is zero when $a=0$. Taking derivative with respect to $a$, we obtain

$$
J_{x}^{*}\left(t, x+a^{2}\right) \cdot 2 a-2 a J_{x}^{*}(t, x)=2 a \cdot h_{1}(t, x)+h_{2}(t, x), \quad \text { for all }(t, x, a)
$$

Setting $a=0$, we get $h_{2}=0$. It follows that

$$
a \cdot\left[J_{x}^{*}\left(t, x+a^{2}\right)-J_{x}^{*}(t, x)-h_{1}(t, x)\right]=0 \quad \text { for all }(t, x, a)
$$

Hence we have $h_{1}(t, x)=J_{x}^{*}\left(t, x+a^{2}\right)-J_{x}^{*}(t, x)$ for any $a \neq 0$. Sending $a$ to zero yields $h_{1}(t, x)=0$ for all $(t, x)$. Therefore, we obtain from (49) that

$$
J^{*}\left(t, x+a^{2}\right)-J^{*}(t, x)-a^{2} J_{x}^{*}(t, x)=0, \quad \text { for all }(t, x, a)
$$

Taking derivative in $a$ in the above we have

$$
J_{x}^{*}\left(t, x+a^{2}\right)-J_{x}^{*}(t, x)=0, \quad \text { for all }(t, x, a)
$$

Thus $J_{x}^{*}$ is constant in $x$ or $J^{*}$ is affine in $x$, leading to $J^{*}(t, x)=g_{1}(t) x+g_{2}(t)$ for some functions $g_{1}(t)$ and $g_{2}(t)$. The resulting Hamiltonian becomes

$$
H\left(t, x, a, J_{x}^{*}, J_{x x}^{*}, J^{*}\right)=a \sigma \rho g_{1}(t)
$$

This is linear in $a \in \mathcal{A}=(-\infty, \infty)$ and hence the integral $\int_{\mathcal{A}} \exp \left(-\frac{1}{\theta} H\left(t, x, a, J_{x}^{*}, J_{x x}^{*}, J^{*}\right)\right) d a$ does not exist. It follows that $\boldsymbol{\pi}^{*}(\cdot \mid t, x)$ does not exist, which is a contradiction. Therefore, we have shown that under (46), the optimal stochastic policy either does not exist or is not Gaussian when it exists.

Remark 5. The argument above works for $\gamma(a, z)=a^{m}$ for any $m>1$.

# 6 Application: Mean-Variance Hedging of Options 

The MV portfolio selection problem considered in Section 5 is an LQ problem. In this section, we present another application that is non-LQ. Consider an option seller who needs to hedge a short position in a European-style option that expires at time $T$. The option is written on a risky asset whose price process $S$ is described by the SDE (33) with condition (36) satisfied. At the terminal time $T$, the seller pays $G\left(S_{T}\right)$ to the option holder. We assume that the seller's hedging activity will not affect the risky asset price.

To hedge the random payoff, the seller constructs a portfolio consisting of the underlying risky asset and cash. We consider discounted quantities in the problem: the discounted risky asset price $\hat{S}_{t}:=e^{-r_{f} t} S_{t}$ and discounted payoff $\hat{G}\left(\hat{S}_{T}\right):=e^{-r_{f} T} G\left(S_{T}\right)$, where $r_{f}$ is again the constant risk-free interest rate. As an example, for a put option with strike price $\mathcal{K}, G\left(S_{T}\right)=\left(\mathcal{K}-S_{T}\right)^{+}$ $\left(x^{+}:=\max (x, 0)\right.$ ), and $\hat{G}\left(\hat{S}_{T}\right)=\left(\tilde{\mathcal{K}}-\hat{S}_{T}\right)^{+}$, where $\tilde{\mathcal{K}}:=e^{-r_{f} T} \mathcal{K}$. Here $\hat{S}$ follows the SDE

$$
d \hat{S}_{t}=\hat{S}_{t-}\left[\rho \sigma d t+\sigma d W_{t}+\int_{\mathbb{R}}(\exp (z)-1) \widetilde{N}(d t, d z)\right]
$$

where $\rho$ is defined in (35).
We denote the discounted dollar value in the risky asset and the discounted value of the hedging portfolio at time $t$ by $a_{t}$ and $X_{t}$, respectively. As in the MV portfolio selection problem, $a_{t}$ is the control variable and $X$ follows the SDE (34). The seller seeks a hedging policy to minimize the deviation from the terminal payoff. A popular formulation is mean-variance hedging (also known as quadratic hedging), which considers the objective

$$
\min _{a} \mathbb{E}\left[\left(X_{T}^{a}-\hat{G}\left(\hat{S}_{T}\right)\right)^{2}\right]
$$

Note that this expectation is taken under the real-world probability measure, rather than under any martingale measure for option pricing. An advantage of this formulation is that relevant data are observable in real world (but not necessarily in a risk-neutral world). Although objective (50) looks similar to that of the MV portfolio selection problem, the target the hedging portfolio tries to meet is now random instead of constant. Furthermore, the payoff is generally nonlinear in $\hat{S}_{T}$. Thus, MV hedging is not an LQ problem. Also, both $\hat{S}_{t}$ and $X_{t}^{a}$ matter for the hedging decision at time $t$, whereas $\hat{S}_{t}$ is irrelevant for decision in the MV portfolio selection problem. This increase in the state dimension makes the hedging problem much more difficult to solve.

We consider the following exploratory formulation to encourage exploration for learning:

$$
\min _{\boldsymbol{\pi}} \mathbb{E}_{t, x}^{\hat{\mathcal{E}}}\left[\left(X_{T}^{\boldsymbol{\pi}}-\hat{G}\left(\hat{S}_{T}\right)\right)^{2}+\theta \int_{t}^{T} \log \boldsymbol{\pi}\left(a_{s}^{\boldsymbol{\pi}} \mid s, X_{s-}^{\boldsymbol{\pi}}\right) d s\right]
$$

where the discounted value of the hedging portfolio under a stochastic policy $\boldsymbol{\pi}$ follows (39).

# 6.1 Solution of the exploratory control problem 

We consider the HJB equation for problem (51):

$$
\frac{\partial V}{\partial t}+\inf _{\boldsymbol{\pi} \in \mathcal{P}(\mathbb{R})} \int_{\mathbb{R}}\left\{H\left(t, S, x, a, V_{S}, V_{S S}, V_{x}, V_{x x}, V_{S x}, V\right)+\theta \log \boldsymbol{\pi}(a \mid t, S, x)\right\} \boldsymbol{\pi}(a \mid t, S, x) d a=0
$$

with terminal condition $v(T, S, x)=(x-\hat{G}(S))^{2}$. The Hamiltonian of the problem is given by

$$
\begin{aligned}
& H\left(t, S, x, a, V_{S}, V_{S S}, V_{x}, V_{x x}, V_{S x}, V\right) \\
= & \rho \sigma S V_{S}(t, S, x)+\frac{1}{2} \sigma^{2} S^{2} V_{S S}(t, S, x)+a \rho \sigma V_{x}(t, S, x)+\frac{1}{2} a^{2} \sigma^{2} V_{x x}(t, S, x)+a \sigma^{2} S V_{S x}(t, S, x) \\
+ & \int_{\mathbb{R}}\left(V(t, S+\tilde{\gamma}(S, z), x+\gamma(a, z)\right)-V(t, S, x)-\tilde{\gamma}(S, z) V_{S}(t, S, x)-\gamma(a, z) V_{x}(t, S, x)\right) \nu(d z)
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\gamma(a, z)=a(\exp (z)-1)$ and $\tilde{\gamma}(S, z)=S(\exp (z)-1)$.
We make the following ansatz for the solution of the HJB equation (52):

$$
V(t, S, x)=(x-h(t, S))^{2} f(t)+g(t, S)
$$

With this, we can simplify the integral term in the Hamiltonian and obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
& H\left(t, S, x, a, V_{S}, V_{S S}, V_{x}, V_{x x}, V_{S x}, V\right) \\
= & \rho \sigma S V_{S}(t, S, x)+\frac{1}{2} \sigma^{2} S^{2} V_{S S}(t, S, x)+\frac{1}{2} a^{2}\left(\sigma^{2}+\sigma_{J}^{2}\right) V_{x x}(t, S, x) \\
& +a\left(\rho \sigma V_{x}(t, S, x)+\sigma^{2} S V_{S x}-\int_{\mathbb{R}}(\exp (z)-1)(h(t, S \exp (z))-h(t, S)) \nu(d z)\right) \\
& +\int_{\mathbb{R}}\left(V(t, S \exp (z), x)-V(t, S, x)-S(\exp (z)-1) V_{S}(t, S, x)\right) \nu(d z)
\end{aligned}
$$

The probability density function that minimizes the integral in (52) is given by

$$
\boldsymbol{\pi}_{c}(\cdot \mid t, S, x) \propto \exp \left(-\frac{1}{\theta} H\left(t, S, x, a, V_{S}, V_{S S}, V_{x}, V_{x x}, V_{S x}, V\right)\right)
$$

which is a candidate for the optimal stochastic policy. From (54), we obtain that $\boldsymbol{\pi}_{c}(\cdot \mid t, S, x)$ is given by

$$
\mathcal{N}\left(\cdot \left\lvert\,-\frac{\rho \sigma V_{x}+\sigma^{2} S V_{S x}-\int_{\mathbb{R}}(\exp (z)-1)(h(t, S \exp (z))-h(t, S)) \nu(d z) V_{x x}}{\left(\sigma^{2}+\sigma_{J}^{2}\right) V_{x x}}\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\right.\

Next, we provide stochastic representations for the solutions to PIDEs (55) and (56), which will be subsequently exploited for our RL study. Construct a new probability measure $\mathbb{Q}$ from the given probability measure $\mathbb{P}$ with the Radon-Nikodym density process $\Lambda_{s}:=\left.\frac{d \mathbb{Q}}{d \mathbb{P}}\right|_{\mathcal{F}_{s}}$ defined by

$$
d \Lambda_{s}=-\frac{\rho \sigma}{\sigma^{2}+\sigma_{J}^{2}} \Lambda_{s-}\left[\sigma d W_{s}+\int_{\mathbb{R}}(\exp (z)-1) \widetilde{N}(d s, d z)\right], \Lambda_{t}=1
$$

Condition (36) guarantees that $\left\{\Lambda_{s}: t \leq s \leq T\right\}$ is a true martingale with unit expectation. The standard measure change results yield that, under $\mathbb{Q}$,

$$
W_{s}^{\prime}:=W_{s}+\frac{\rho \sigma^{2}}{\sigma^{2}+\sigma_{J}^{2}}(s-t), \widetilde{N}^{\prime}(d s, d z):=N(d s, d z)-\left[1-\frac{\rho \sigma}{\sigma^{2}+\sigma_{J}^{2}}(\exp (z)-1)\right] \nu(d z) d s
$$

are standard Brownian motion and compensated Poisson random measure, respectively. Using them we can rewrite the SDE for $\hat{S}$ as

$$
d \hat{S}_{s}=\hat{S}_{s-}\left[\sigma d W_{s}^{\prime}+\int_{\mathbb{R}}(\exp (z)-1) \widetilde{N}^{\prime}(d s, d z)\right]
$$

Let $Y_{t}:=1+\sigma W_{t}+\int_{0}^{t} \int_{\mathbb{R}}(\exp (z)-1) \widetilde{N}^{\prime}(d s, d z)$. Clearly, it is a Lévy process and also a martingale under condition (36). Process $\hat{S}$ is the stochastic exponential of $Y$ and it follows from (Cont and Tankov 2004, Proposition 8.23) that $\hat{S}$ is also a martingale under $\mathbb{Q}$. The Feynman-Kac theorem gives the representation of the solution $h$ to $\operatorname{PIDE}$ (55) as

$$
h(t, S)=\mathbb{E}^{\mathbb{Q}}\left[\hat{G}\left(\hat{S}_{T}\right) \mid \hat{S}_{t}=S\right], \quad t \in[0, T]
$$

We can view $\mathbb{Q}$ as the martingale measure for option valuation and interpret $h(t, S)$ as the option price at time $t$ and underlying price $S$. For $\operatorname{PIDE}$ (56), again by the Feynman-Kac theorem we obtain that its solution $g$ is given by

$$
\begin{aligned}
g(t, S) & =g_{e}(t, S)-\int_{t}^{T} \frac{\theta}{2} \ln \frac{\pi \theta}{\left(\sigma^{2}+\sigma_{J}^{2}\right) f(s)} d s \\
& =g_{e}(t, S)-\frac{\theta}{2}\left[\ln \left(\frac{\pi \theta}{\sigma^{2}+\sigma_{J}^{2}}\right)(T-t)+\frac{\rho^{2} \sigma^{2}}{2\left(\sigma^{2}+\sigma_{J}^{2}\right)}(T-t)^{2}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

where

$$
\begin{aligned}
& g_{e}(t, S):=\mathbb{E}^{\mathbb{P}}\left[\int_{t}^{T} f(s)\left(\sigma^{2} \hat{S}_{s}^{2}\left(h_{S}\left(s, \hat{S}_{s}\right)\right)^{2}+\int_{\mathbb{R}}\left(h\left(s, \hat{S}_{s} \exp (z)\right)-h\left(s, \hat{S}_{s}\right)\right)^{2} \nu(d z)\right) d s \\
& \quad-\int_{t}^{T} \frac{f(s)}{\sigma^{2}+\sigma_{J}^{2}}\left(\sigma^{2} \hat{S}_{s} h_{S}\left(s, \hat{S}_{s}\right)+\int_{\mathbb{R}}(\exp (z)-1)\left(h\left(s, \hat{S}_{s} \exp (z)\right)-h\left(s, \hat{S}_{s}\right)\right) \nu(d z)\right)^{2} d s \mid \hat{S}_{t}=S
\end{aligned}
$$

Using the expression for $V(t, S, x)$, we obtain $\boldsymbol{\pi}_{c}(\cdot \mid t, S, x)$ as

$$
\boldsymbol{\pi}_{c}(\cdot \mid t, S, x) \sim \mathcal{N}\left(\cdot \mid \mathcal{M}^{*}(t, S, x), \frac{\theta}{2\left(\sigma^{2}+\sigma_{J}^{2}\right)} \exp \left(\frac{\rho^{2} \sigma^{2}}{\sigma^{2}+\sigma_{J}^{2}}(T-t)\right)\right)
$$

where

$$
\mathcal{M}^{*}(t, S, x)=\frac{\sigma^{2} S h_{S}(t, S)+\int_{\mathbb{R}}(\exp (z)-1)(h(t, S \exp (z))-h(t, S)) \nu(d z)-\rho \sigma(x-h(t, S))}{\sigma^{2}+\sigma_{J}^{2}}
$$

Using Lemma 6, we can directly verify that $\boldsymbol{\pi}_{c}$ is admissible. It is also obvious to see that $V(t, S, x)$ given by (53) has quadratic growth in $S$ and $x$. Therefore, by Lemma 5, we have the following conclusion.

Proposition 3. For the MV hedging problem (50), the optimal value function $J^{*}(t, S, x)=V(t, S, x)$ and the optimal stochastic policy $\boldsymbol{\pi}^{*}=\boldsymbol{\pi}_{c}$ under the assumptions that $\sigma>0$ and $\tilde{G}(S)$ is Lipschitz continuous in $S$.

The mean part of $\boldsymbol{\pi}^{*}, \mathcal{M}^{*}(t, S, x)$, comprises three terms. The quantity $h_{S}(t, S)$ is the delta of the option and hence $S h_{S}(t, S)$ gives the dollar amount of the risky asset as required by delta hedging, which is used to hedge continuous price movements. The integral term shows the dollar amount of the risky asset that should be held to hedge discontinuous changes. The two hedges are combined using weights $\sigma^{2} /\left(\sigma^{2}+\sigma_{J}^{2}\right)$ and $1 /\left(\sigma^{2}+\sigma_{J}^{2}\right)$. The last term reflects the adjustment that needs to be made due to the discrepancy between the hedging portfolio value and option price. It is easy to show that $\mathcal{M}^{*}(t, S, x)$ is the optimal deterministic policy of problem (50).

The variance of $\boldsymbol{\pi}^{*}$ is the same as that in the MV portfolio selection problem (c.f. (43)), which decreases as $t$ approaches the terminal time $T$. This implies that one gradually reduces exploration over time.

# 6.2 Parametrizations and actor-critic learning 

We use the previously derived solution of the exploratory problem as knowledge for RL. As we will see, the exploratory solution lends itself to natural parametrizations for the policy ("actor") and value function ("critic"), but less so for parametrizing the $q$-function.

To simplify the integral in $\mathcal{M}^{*}(t, S, x)$ defined in (63), we first parametrize the Lévy density $\nu(z)$ as in (44) where we have three parameters: $\lambda$ is the jump arrival rate, and $m$ and $\delta$ are the mean and standard deviation of the normal distribution for the jump size. We then use the Fourier-cosine method developed in Fang and Oosterlee (2009) to obtain an expression for $h(t, S)$. Let $Y_{t}:=\log \left(\hat{S}_{t} / \hat{S}_{0}\right)$. Applying Itô's formula, under $\mathbb{P}$ we obtain

$$
d \log \hat{S}_{t}=\left[\rho \sigma-\frac{1}{2} \sigma^{2}-\lambda\left(\exp \left(m+\frac{1}{2} \delta^{2}\right)-1\right)\right] d t+\sigma d W_{t}+\int_{\mathbb{R}} z N(d t, d z)
$$

Noting (58), under $\mathbb{Q}$ we have

$$
d \log \hat{S}_{t}=\left[\rho \sigma \frac{\sigma_{J}^{2}}{\sigma^{2}+\sigma_{J}^{2}}-\frac{1}{2} \sigma^{2}-\lambda\left(\exp \left(m+\frac{1}{2} \delta^{2}\right)-1\right)\right] d t+\sigma d W_{t}^{\prime}+\int_{\mathbb{R}} z N(d t, d z)
$$

where the Lévy measure of $N(d t, d z)$ becomes

$$
\nu^{\prime}(d z)=\left[1-\frac{\rho \sigma}{\sigma^{2}+\sigma_{J}^{2}}(\exp (z)-1)\right] \frac{\lambda}{\sqrt{2 \pi \delta^{2}}} \exp \left(-\frac{(z-m)^{2}}{2 \delta^{2}}\right) d z
$$

The characteristic function of $Y_{t}$ under $\mathbb{Q}$ is given by

$$
\Phi_{Y_{t}}^{\mathbb{Q}}(u)=\exp \left[i u t\left(\rho \sigma \frac{\sigma_{J}^{2}}{\sigma^{2}+\sigma_{J}^{2}}-\frac{1}{2} \sigma^{2}-\lambda\left(\exp \left(m+\frac{1}{2} \delta^{2}\right)-1\right)\right)-\frac{1}{2} \sigma^{2} u^{2} t+t A(u)\right]
$$

where

$$
\begin{aligned}
A(u)= & \int_{\mathbb{R}}(\exp (i u z)-1) \nu^{\prime}(d z) \\
= & \lambda\left(\exp \left(i u m-\frac{1}{2} \delta^{2} u^{2}\right)-1\right)-\frac{\lambda \rho \sigma}{\sigma^{2}+\sigma_{J}^{2}} \times \\
& \left(\exp \left(m+\frac{1}{2} \delta^{2}+i u\left(m+\delta^{2}\right)-\frac{1}{2} \delta^{2} u^{2}\right)-\exp \left(i u m-\frac{1}{2} \delta^{2} u^{2}\right)-\exp \left(m+\frac{1}{2} \delta^{2}\right)+1\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

The Fourier-cosine method then calculates $h(t, S)$ as

$$
\hat{h}(t, S):=\sum_{k=0}^{N-1} \Re\left(\Phi_{Y_{t}}^{\mathbb{Q}}\left(\frac{k \pi}{b-a}\right) \exp \left(i k \pi \frac{\ln (S / \hat{\mathcal{K}})-a}{b-a}\right)\right) V_{k}
$$

Here, $\Re(x)$ denotes the real part of complex number $x, \Sigma^{\prime}$ indicates the first term in the sum is halved, $\hat{\mathcal{K}}$ is the discounted strike price of the call or put option under consideration, and $[a, b]$ is the truncation region for $Y_{T}$ (chosen wide enough so that the probability of $Y_{T}$ going outside under $\mathbb{Q}$ can be neglected). The expression of $V_{k}$ is given by Eqs. (24) and (25) in Fang and Oosterlee (2009) for call and put options, respectively, and it only depends on $a, b, \hat{\mathcal{K}}$. We can also calculate $h_{S}(t, S)$ by differentiating $\hat{h}(t, S)$ w.r.t. $S$, which yields

$$
\hat{h}_{S}(t, S):=\sum_{k=0}^{N-1} \Re\left(\Phi_{Y_{t}}^{\mathbb{Q}}\left(\frac{k \pi}{b-a}\right) \frac{i k \pi}{(b-a) S} \exp \left(i k \pi \frac{\ln (S / \hat{\mathcal{K}})-a}{b-a}\right)\right) V_{k}
$$

Actor parametrization. We follow the form of the optimal stochastic policy given in (62) to parametrize our policy. To obtain a parsimonious parametrization, we introduce $\phi_{1}, \phi_{2}, \phi_{3}, \phi_{4}, \phi_{5}$, which respectively represent the agent's understanding - relative to her learning - of drift $\mu$, volatility $\sigma$, jump arrival rate $\lambda$, mean $m$ and standard deviation $\delta$ of the jump size of the risky asset. We emphasize that in our learning algorithm these parameters are not estimated by any statistical method (and hence they do not necessarily correspond to the true dynamics of the risky asset); rather they will be updated based on the hedging experiences (via exploration and exploitation) from the real environment. To implement (62), we also need two dependent parameters $\phi_{6}$ and $\phi_{7}$ that are calculated by

$$
\phi_{6}=\frac{\phi_{1}-r_{f}}{\phi_{2}}, \phi_{7}=\sqrt{\phi_{3}\left[\exp \left(2 \phi_{4}+2 \phi_{5}^{2}\right)-2 \exp \left(\phi_{4}+\frac{1}{2} \phi_{5}^{2}\right)+1\right]}
$$

These two parameters show the agent's understanding of $\rho$ and $\sigma_{J}$, and they will be updated in the learning process by the above equations with the update of the independent parameters $\phi_{1}$ to $\phi_{5}$. Denote $\phi=\left(\phi_{i}\right)_{i=1}^{7}$.

We use $\phi_{1}, \phi_{2}, \phi_{3}, \phi_{4}, \phi_{5}, \phi_{6}, \phi_{7}$ to replace their counterparts $\mu, \sigma, \lambda, m, \delta, \rho, \sigma_{J}$ in (62) to obtain a parametrized policy. For the mean part, we calculate the option price and its delta by plugging $\phi$

into (64) and (65), with the results denoted by $\hat{h}^{\phi}(t, S)$ and $\hat{h}_{S}^{\phi}(t, S)$ respectively, and approximate the integral by Gauss-Hermite (G-H) quadrature, which yields
$\mathcal{M}^{\phi}(t, S, x)=\frac{\phi_{2}^{2} S \hat{h}_{S}^{\phi}(t, S)+\frac{\phi_{3}}{\sqrt{2 \pi}} \sum_{q=1}^{Q} w_{q}\left(\exp \left(z_{q}\right)-1\right)\left(\hat{h}^{\phi}\left(t, S \exp \left(z_{q}\right)\right)-\hat{h}^{\phi}(t, S)\right)-\phi_{2} \phi_{6}\left(x-\hat{h}^{\phi}(t, S)\right)}{\phi_{2}^{2}+\phi_{7}^{2}}$,
where $z_{q}=\phi_{4}+\phi_{5} u_{q}$ and $\left\{\left(w_{q}, u_{q}\right), q=1, \cdots, Q\right\}$ are the weights and abscissa of the $Q$-point G-H rule that are predetermined and independent of $\phi$. For the variance part, we use $\phi$ in (57) to obtain $f^{\phi}(t)$. Thus, our parametrized policy is given by

$$
\boldsymbol{\pi}^{\phi}(\cdot \mid t, S, x) \sim \mathcal{N}\left(\cdot \mid \mathcal{M}^{\phi}(t, S, x), \frac{\theta}{2\left(\phi_{2}^{2}+\phi_{7}^{2}\right) f^{\phi}(t)}\right)
$$

Critic parametrization. For the value function of $\boldsymbol{\pi}^{\phi}$, following (53) we parametrize it as

$$
J^{\psi, \phi}(t, S, x)=\left(x-\hat{h}^{\phi}(t, S)\right)^{2} f^{\phi}(t)+g_{e}^{\psi}(t, S)-\frac{\theta}{2}\left[\ln \left(\frac{\pi \theta}{\phi_{2}^{2}+\phi_{7}^{2}}\right)(T-t)+\frac{\phi_{3}^{2} \phi_{6}^{2}}{2\left(\phi_{2}^{2}+\phi_{7}^{2}\right)}(T-t)^{2}\right]
$$

We do not specify any parametric form for $g_{e}^{\psi}(t, S)$, but will learn it using Gaussian process regression (Williams and Rasmussen 2006), where $\psi$ denotes its parameters. We choose Gaussian process for our problem because it is able to generate flexible shapes and can often achieve a reasonably good fit with a moderate amount of data.

Actor-critic learning. Consider a time grid $\left\{t_{k}\right\}_{k=0}^{K}$ with $t_{0}=0, t_{K}=T$, and time step $\Delta t$. In an iteration, we start with a given policy $\boldsymbol{\pi}^{\phi}$ and use it to collect $M$ episodes from the environment, where the $m$-th episode is given by $\left\{\left(t_{k}, \hat{S}_{t_{k}}^{(m)}, X_{t_{k}}^{\boldsymbol{\pi}^{\phi},(m)}, a_{t_{k}}^{\boldsymbol{\pi}^{\phi},(m)}\right)\right\}_{k=0}^{K}$. We then perform two steps.

In the critic step, the main task is to learn $g_{e}^{\psi}\left(t_{k}, S\right)$ as a function of $S$ for each $t_{k}$. The stochastic representation (61) shows that $g_{e}$ can be viewed as the value function of a stream of rewards that depend on time and the risky asset price; so the task is a policy evaluation problem. We first obtain the running reward path in every episode, where the integral involving the Lévy measure is again calculated by the $Q$-point G-H rule. Specifically, the reward at time $t_{k}$ for $k=0, \cdots, K-1$ is given by

$$
\begin{aligned}
& R_{t_{k}}^{g}:=f^{\phi}\left(t_{k}\right)\left[\phi_{2}^{2} \hat{S}_{t_{k}}^{g}\left(\hat{h}_{S}^{\phi}\left(t_{k}, \hat{S}_{t_{k}}\right)\right)^{2}+\frac{\phi_{3}}{\sqrt{2 \pi}} \sum_{q=1}^{Q} w_{q}\left(\hat{h}^{\phi}\left(t_{k}, \hat{S}_{t_{k}} \exp \left(z_{q}\right)\right)-\hat{h}^{\phi}\left(t_{k}, \hat{S}_{t_{k}}\right)\right)^{2}\right] \Delta t \\
& -\frac{f^{\phi}\left(t_{k}\right)}{\phi_{2}^{2}+\phi_{7}^{2}}\left[\phi_{2}^{2} \hat{S}_{t_{k}} \hat{h}_{S}^{\phi}\left(t_{k}, \hat{S}_{t_{k}}\right)+\frac{\phi_{3}}{\sqrt{2 \pi}} \sum_{q=1}^{Q} w_{q}\left(\exp \left(z_{q}\right)-1\right)\left(\hat{h}^{\phi}\left(t_{k}, \hat{S}_{t_{k}} \exp \left(z_{q}\right)\right)-\hat{h}^{\phi}\left(t_{k}, \hat{S}_{t_{k}}\right)\right)\right]^{2} \Delta t
\end{aligned}
$$

where the risky asset price path $\left\{\left(\hat{S}_{t_{k}}\right)\right\}_{k=0}^{K-1}$ is collected from the real environment. We stress again that the above calculation uses the agent's parameters $\phi$ and does not involve any parameters of the true dynamics. We then fit a Gaussian process to the sample of the cumulative rewards $\left\{\sum_{\ell=k}^{K-1} R_{t_{\ell}}^{g,(m)}\right\}_{m=1}^{M}$ to estimate $g_{e}^{\psi}\left(t_{k}, S\right)$. Figure 2 illustrates the fit at three time points with the radial basis kernel. The Gaussian process is able to provide a good fit to the shape of $g_{e}(t, S)$ as a function of $S$ for each given $t$.

In the actor step, we update the policy parameter $\phi_{i}$ for $i=1, \cdots, 5$ by

$$
\begin{aligned}
\phi_{i} \leftarrow & \phi_{i}-\frac{\alpha_{\phi_{i}}}{M} \sum_{m=1}^{M} \sum_{k=0}^{K-1}\left[\theta \log \boldsymbol{\pi}^{\phi}\left(\dot{a}_{t_{k}}^{\boldsymbol{\pi}^{\phi},(m)} \mid t_{k}, \dot{S}_{t_{k}}^{(m)}, X_{t_{k}}^{\boldsymbol{\pi}^{\phi},(m)}\right) \Delta t\right. \\
& \left.+J^{\psi, \phi}\left(t_{k+1}, \dot{S}_{t_{k+1}}^{(m)}, X_{t_{k+1}}^{\boldsymbol{\pi}^{\phi},(m)}\right)-J^{\psi, \phi}\left(t_{k}, \dot{S}_{t_{k}}^{(m)}, X_{t_{k}}^{\boldsymbol{\pi}^{\phi},(m)}\right)-\beta J^{\psi, \phi}\left(t_{k}, X_{t_{k}}^{\boldsymbol{\pi}^{\phi},(m)}\right) \Delta t\right] \\
& \cdot \frac{\partial}{\partial \phi_{i}} \log \boldsymbol{\pi}^{\phi}\left(\dot{a}_{t_{k}}^{\boldsymbol{\pi}^{\phi},(m)} \mid t_{k}, \dot{S}_{t_{k}}^{(m)}, X_{t_{k}}^{\boldsymbol{\pi}^{\phi},(m)}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

This update essentially follows from (32); the difference is that we do batch processing and update the parameters only after observing all the episodes in a batch. Furthermore, we flip the sign before $\alpha_{\phi_{i}}$ and $\theta$ as we consider minimization here while the problem in the general discussion is for maximization.

# 6.3 Simulation study 

We check the convergence behavior of our actor-critic algorithm in a simulation study. We assume the environment is described by an MJD model with its true parameters shown in the upper row of Table 2. ${ }^{2}$ We consider hedging a 4-month put option with strike price $\mathcal{K}=100$ because short-term options with maturity of a few months are typically traded much more actively than longer-term options. We assume the risk-free rate is zero.

We use 20 quadrature points for the G-H rule in our implementation, which suffices for high accuracy. In each iteration, we sample $M=32$ episodes from the environment simulated by the MJD model. The learning rates are chosen to be $\alpha_{\phi_{1}}=5 \mathrm{e}-3, \alpha_{\phi_{2}}=2 \mathrm{e}-5, \alpha_{\phi_{3}}=15, \alpha_{\phi_{4}}=1 \mathrm{e}-6$, $\alpha_{\phi_{5}}=1 \mathrm{e}-6$, while the temperature parameter $\theta=0.1$. We keep the learning rates constant in the first 30 iterations and then they decay at rate $l(j)=j^{-0.5}$, where $j$ is the iteration index.

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{2}$ These values are chosen close to the estimates obtained from the market data of S\&P 500 in Table 1 to make the MJD model better resemble the reality in the simulation study.

Before our actor-critic learning, we sample a 15-year path from the MJD model as data for MLE and obtain estimates of the parameters shown in Table 2. MLE estimates all the parameters quite well except the drift $\mu$, where the estimate is more than twice the true value. ${ }^{3}$ We then use these estimates as initial values of $\phi_{1}$ to $\phi_{5}$ for learning. Figure 3 clearly shows that our RL algorithm is able to converge near the true values. In particular, the estimate of $\mu$ eventually moves closely around the true level despite being distant to it initially.

# 6.4 Empirical study 

In the empirical study we consider hedging a European put option written on the S\&P 500 index. This type of option is popular in the financial market as a tool for investors to protect their high beta investment. We obtain daily observations of the index from the beginning of 2000 to the end of 2023 , and split them into two periods: the training period (the first 20 years) and the test period (the last 4 years). The test period includes the U.S. stock market meltdown at the onset of the pandemic, the 2022 bear period, and various bull periods.

We use the MLE estimates from the first 20 years of observations to initialize $\phi_{1}$ to $\phi_{5}$ for learning. To sample an episode from the environment for training our RL algorithm, we bootstrap index returns from the training period. Similarly, we bootstrap index returns from the test period to generate index price paths to test the learned policy. We use the 20 -point G-H rule with $M=32$ episodes in each training iteration. The learning rates are set as $\alpha_{\phi_{1}}=5 \mathrm{e}-3, \alpha_{\phi_{2}}=5 \mathrm{e}-4, \alpha_{\phi_{3}}=50$, $\alpha_{\phi_{4}}=5 \mathrm{e}-6, \alpha_{\phi_{5}}=1 \mathrm{e}-5$ with the same learning rate decay schedule as in the simulation study. We set the temperature parameter $\theta=0.1$.

We consider four maturities ranging from 1 to 4 months for the put option. For a standard S\&P500 index option traded on CBOE, in practice its strike is quoted in points commensurate with the scale of the index level and converted to dollar amount by a multiplier of 100 . That is,

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{3}$ This is expected due to the well-known mean-blur problem, as 15 years of data are significantly insufficient to obtain a reasonably accurate estimate of the mean using statistical methods.

the dollar strike $\mathcal{K}=100 \mathcal{K}_{p}$, where $\mathcal{K}_{p}$ is the strike in points. ${ }^{4}$ Let $S_{t}$ be the index level at time $t$ converted to dollars by the multiplier of 100 . We sample $S_{0}$ uniformly from the range $[0.7 \mathcal{K}, 1.3 \mathcal{K}]$ to generate training and test episodes. This allows us to include scenarios where the option is deep out of money or in the money. We train our algorithm for 100 iterations and then test it on 5000 index price episodes. Finally, although we use a stochastic policy to interact with the environment for learning/updating the parameters during training, in the test stage we apply a deterministic policy which is the mean of the learned stochastic policy. This can reduce the variance of the final hedging error.

To measure the test performance, we consider the mean squared hedging error (denominated in squared dollars) divided by $\mathcal{K}_{p}^{2}$. This effectively normalizes the contract's scale; so we can just set $\mathcal{K}_{p}=1$ in our implementation. The test result can be interpreted as the average mean squared hedging error in squared dollars for every point of strike price.

We compare the performances of the policy learned by our RL algorithm and the one obtained by plugging the MLE estimates from the training period data to (63). Both policies are tested on the same index price episodes. We check the statistical significance of the difference in the squared hedging errors of the two policies by applying the t-test. Table 3 reports the mean squared hedging error for each policy as well as the p-value of the t-test. Not surprisingly, the hedging error of each policy increases as the maturity becomes longer due to greater uncertainty in the problem. In every case, the RL policy achieves notable reduction in the hedging error compared with the MLE-based policy. The p-value further shows the outperformance of the former is statistically significant.

# 7 Conclusions 

Fluctuations in data or time series coming from nonlinear, complex dynamic systems are characterized by two types: slow changes and sudden jumps, the latter occurring much rarely than the former. Hence jump-diffusions capture the key structural characteristics of many data generating processes in areas such as physics, astrophysics, earth science, engineering, finance, and medicine. As a result, RL for jump-diffusions is important both theoretically and practically. This paper endeavors to lay a theoretical foundation for the study. A key insight from this research is that temporal-difference algorithms designed for diffusions can work seamlessly for jump-diffusions. However, unless using general neural networks, policy parameterization does need to respond to the presence of jumps if one is to take advantage of any special structure of an underlying problem.

There are plenty of open questions starting from here, including the convergence of the algorithms, regret bounds, decaying rates of the temperature parameters, and learning rates of the gradient decent and/or stochastic approximation procedures involved.

# A Proofs 

Proof of Lemma 2. We observe that for each $k=1, \cdots, \ell$,

$$
\int_{\mathbb{R} \times[0,1]^{n}}\left|\gamma_{k}\left(t, x, G^{\boldsymbol{\pi}_{t, x}}(u), z\right)\right|^{p} \nu_{k}(d z) d u=\int_{\mathcal{A}} \int_{\mathbb{R}}\left|\gamma_{k}(t, x, a, z)\right|^{p} \nu_{k}(d z) \boldsymbol{\pi}(a \mid t, x) d a
$$

From Assumption 1-(iii), we have $\sum_{k=1}^{\ell} \int_{\mathbb{R}}\left|\gamma_{k}(t, x, a, z)\right|^{p} \nu_{k}(d z) \leq C_{p}\left(1+|x|^{p}\right)$ for any $(t, x, a) \in$ $[0, T] \times \mathbb{R}^{d} \times \mathcal{A}$, where $C_{p}$ does not depend on $a$. Thus, integrating over $a$ with the measure $\boldsymbol{\pi}(a \mid t, x) d a$ preserves the linear growth property.

Proof of Lemma 3. We consider

$$
\int_{\mathbb{R} \times[0,1]^{n}}\left|\gamma_{k}\left(t, x, G^{\boldsymbol{\pi}_{t, x}}(u), z\right)-\gamma_{k}\left(t, x^{\prime}, G^{\boldsymbol{\pi}_{t, x^{\prime}}}(u), z\right)\right|^{p} \nu_{k}(d z) d u
$$

which is bounded by

$$
\begin{aligned}
C_{p} & \left(\int_{\mathbb{R} \times[0,1]^{n}}\left|\gamma_{k}\left(t, x, G^{\boldsymbol{\pi}_{t, x}}(u), z\right)-\gamma_{k}\left(t, x, G^{\boldsymbol{\pi}_{t, x^{\prime}}}(u), z\right)\right|^{p} \nu_{k}(d z) d u\right. \\
& \left.+\int_{\mathbb{R} \times[0,1]^{n}}\left|\gamma_{k}\left(t, x, G^{\boldsymbol{\pi}_{t, x^{\prime}}}(u), z\right)-\gamma_{k}\left(t, x^{\prime}, G^{\boldsymbol{\pi}_{t, x^{\prime}}}(u), z\right)\right|^{p} \nu_{k}(d z) d u\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

for some constant $C_{p}>0$.
For the first integral, using Assumption 2 we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int_{\mathbb{R} \times[0,1]^{n}}\left|\gamma_{k}\left(t, x, G^{\boldsymbol{\pi}_{t, x}}(u), z\right)-\gamma_{k}\left(t, x, G^{\boldsymbol{\pi}_{t, x^{\prime}}}(u), z\right)\right|^{p} \nu_{k}(d z) d u \\
\leq & C_{K, p} \int_{[0,1]^{n}}\left|G^{\boldsymbol{\pi}}(t, x, u)-G^{\boldsymbol{\pi}}\left(t, x^{\prime}, u\right)\right|^{p} d u \leq C_{K, p}^{\prime}\left|x-x^{\prime}\right|^{p}
\end{aligned}
$$

For the second integral, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int_{\mathbb{R} \times[0,1]^{n}}\left|\gamma_{k}\left(t, x, G^{\boldsymbol{\pi}_{t, x^{\prime}}}(u), z\right)-\gamma_{k}\left(t, x^{\prime}, G^{\boldsymbol{\pi}_{t, x^{\prime}}}(u), z\right)\right|^{p} \nu_{k}(d z) d u \\
= & \int_{\mathcal{A}} \int_{\mathbb{R}}\left|\gamma_{k}(t, x, a, z)-\gamma_{k}\left(t, x^{\prime}, a, z\right)\right|^{p} \nu_{k}(d z) \boldsymbol{\pi}\left(a \mid t, x^{\prime}\right) d a \\
\leq & \int_{\mathcal{A}} C_{K, p}^{\prime \prime}\left|x-x^{\prime}\right|^{p} \boldsymbol{\pi}\left(a \mid t, x^{\prime}\right) d a \\
= & C_{K, p}^{\prime \prime}\left|x-x^{\prime}\right|^{p}
\end{aligned}
$$

where we used Assumption 1-(ii) and $C_{K, p}^{\prime \prime}$ is the constant there. The desired claim is obtained by combining these results.

Proof of Lemma 4. Fix $t \in[0, T)$ and suppose $\tilde{X}_{t}^{\pi}=x$. Define a sequence of stopping times $\tau_{n}=\inf \left\{s \geq t:\left|\tilde{X}_{s}^{\pi}\right| \geq n\right\}$ for $n \in \mathbb{N}$. Applying Itô's formula (6) to the process $e^{-\beta s} \phi\left(s, \tilde{X}_{s}^{\pi}\right)$, where $\tilde{X}_{s}^{\pi}$ follows the exploratory $\operatorname{SDE}$ (18), we obtain $\forall t^{\prime} \in[t, T]$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& e^{-\beta\left(t^{\prime} \wedge \tau_{n}\right)} \phi\left(t^{\prime} \wedge \tau_{n}, \tilde{X}_{r \wedge \tau_{n}}^{\pi}\right)-e^{-\beta t} \phi(t, x) \\
= & \int_{t}^{t^{\prime} \wedge \tau_{n}} e^{-\beta s}\left(\mathcal{L}^{\pi} \phi\left(s, \tilde{X}_{s-}^{\pi}\right)-\beta \phi\left(s, \tilde{X}_{s-}^{\pi}\right)\right) d s \\
+ & \int_{t}^{t^{\prime} \wedge \tau_{n}} e^{-\beta s} \phi_{x}\left(s, \tilde{X}_{s-}^{\pi}\right) \circ \tilde{\sigma}\left(s, \tilde{X}_{s-}^{\pi}, \pi\left(\cdot \mid s, \tilde{X}_{s-}^{\pi}\right)\right) d W_{s} \\
+ & \int_{t}^{t^{\prime} \wedge \tau_{n}} e^{-\beta s} \sum_{k=1}^{\ell} \int_{\mathbb{R} \times[0,1]^{n}}\left(\phi\left(s, \tilde{X}_{s-}^{\pi}+\gamma_{k}\left(s, \tilde{X}_{s-}^{\pi}, G_{\pi}\left(s, \tilde{X}_{s-}^{\pi}, u\right), z\right)\right)-\phi\left(s, \tilde{X}_{s-}^{\pi}\right)\right) \widetilde{N}_{k}^{\prime}(d s, d z, d u)
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\mathcal{L}^{\pi}$ is the generator of the exploratory process $\left(\tilde{X}_{t}^{\pi}\right)$ given in (17). We next show that the expectations of (66) and (67) are zero.

Note that for $s \in\left[t, t^{\prime} \wedge \tau_{n}\right],\left|\tilde{X}_{s-}^{\pi}\right| \leq n$. Thus, $\phi_{x}\left(s, \tilde{X}_{s-}^{\pi}\right)$ is also bounded. Using the linear growth of $\tilde{\sigma}\left(s, \tilde{X}_{s-}^{\pi}, \pi\left(\cdot \mid s, \tilde{X}_{s-}^{\pi}\right)\right)$ in Lemma 1 and the moment estimate (19), we can see that (66) is a square-integrable martingale and hence its expectation is zero.

Next, we analyze the following stochastic integral:

$$
\int_{t}^{t^{\prime} \wedge \tau_{n}} e^{-\beta s} \int_{\mathbb{R} \times[0,1]^{n}}\left(\phi\left(s, \tilde{X}_{s-}^{\pi}+\gamma_{k}\left(s, \tilde{X}_{s-}^{\pi}, G_{\pi}\left(s, \tilde{X}_{s-}^{\pi}, u\right), z\right)\right)-\phi\left(s, \tilde{X}_{s-}^{\pi}\right)\right) \widetilde{N}_{k}(d s, d z, d u)
$$

We consider the finite and infinite jump activity cases separately.
Case 1: $\int_{\mathbb{R}} \nu_{k}(d z)<\infty$. In this case, both of the processes

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int_{t}^{t^{\prime} \wedge \tau_{n}} e^{-\beta s} \int_{\mathbb{R} \times[0,1]^{n}} \phi\left(s, \tilde{X}_{s-}^{\pi}+\gamma_{k}\left(s, \tilde{X}_{s-}^{\pi}, G_{\pi}\left(s, \tilde{X}_{s-}^{\pi}, u\right), z\right)\right) \widetilde{N}_{k}(d s, d z, d u) \\
& \int_{t}^{t^{\prime} \wedge \tau_{n}} e^{-\beta s} \int_{\mathbb{R} \times[0,1]^{n}} \phi\left(s, \tilde{X}_{s-}^{\pi}\right) \widetilde{N}_{k}(d s, d z, d u)
\end{aligned}
$$

are square-integrable martingales and hence have zero expectations. We prove this claim for (69) and analyzing (70) is entirely analogous.

Using the polynomial growth of $\phi$, Lemma 2, and $\left|\tilde{X}_{s-}^{\pi}\right| \leq n$ for $s \in\left[t, t^{\prime} \wedge \tau_{n}\right]$, we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathbb{E}_{t, x}^{\S}\left[\int_{t}^{t^{\prime} \wedge \tau_{n}} e^{-2 \beta s} \int_{\mathbb{R} \times[0,1]^{n}}\left|\phi\left(s, \tilde{X}_{s-}^{\pi}+\gamma_{k}\left(s, \tilde{X}_{s-}^{\pi}, G_{\pi}\left(s, \tilde{X}_{s-}^{\pi}, u\right), z\right)\right)\right|^{2} \nu_{k}(d z) d u d s\right] \\
\leq & C_{p} \cdot \mathbb{E}_{t, x}^{\S}\left[\int_{t}^{t^{\prime} \wedge \tau_{n}} \int_{\mathbb{R} \times[0,1]^{n}}\left(1+\left|\tilde{X}_{s-}^{\pi}\right|^{p}+\left|\gamma_{k}\left(s, \tilde{X}_{s-}^{\pi}, G_{\pi}\left(s, \tilde{X}_{s-}^{\pi}, u\right), z\right)\right)\right|^{p}\right) \nu_{k}(d z) d u d s\right] \\
\leq & C_{p}^{\prime} \cdot \mathbb{E}_{t, x}^{\S}\left[\int_{t}^{t^{\prime} \wedge \tau_{n}}\left(1+\left|\tilde{X}_{s-}^{\pi}\right|^{p}\right) d s\right]<\infty
\end{aligned}
$$

This implies the process (69) is a square-integrable martingale; see e.g. (Situ 2006, Section 1.9) for square-integrability of stochastic integrals with respect to compensated Poisson random measures.

Case 2: $\int_{\mathbb{R}} \nu_{k}(d z)=\infty$. Let $B_{1}=\left\{|z| \leq 1\right\} \times[0,1]^{n}$ and $B_{1}^{c}=\left\{|z|>1\right\} \times[0,1]^{n}$. The stochastic integral (68) can be written as the sum of two integrals:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int_{t}^{t^{\prime} \wedge \tau_{n}} e^{-\beta s} \int_{B_{1}}\left(\phi\left(s, \tilde{X}_{s-}^{\pi}+\gamma_{k}\left(s, \tilde{X}_{s-}^{\pi}, G_{\pi}\left(s, \tilde{X}_{s-}^{\pi}, u\right), z\right)\right)-\phi\left(s, \tilde{X}_{s-}^{\pi}\right)\right) \widetilde{N}_{k}(d s, d z, d u) \\
+ & \int_{t}^{t^{\prime} \wedge \tau_{n}} e^{-\beta s} \int_{B_{1}^{c}}\left(\phi\left(s, \tilde{X}_{s-}^{\pi}+\gamma_{k}\left(s, \tilde{X}_{s-}^{\pi}, G_{\pi}\left(s, \tilde{X}_{s-}^{\pi}, u\right), z\right)\right)-\phi\left(s, \tilde{X}_{s-}^{\pi}\right)\right) \widetilde{N}_{k}(d s, d z, d u)
\end{aligned}
$$

Using the mean-value theorem, the stochastic integral (71) is equal to

$$
\int_{t}^{t^{\prime} \wedge \tau_{n}} e^{-\beta s} \int_{B_{1}} \phi_{x}\left(s, \tilde{X}_{s-}^{\pi}+\alpha_{s} \gamma_{k}\left(s, \tilde{X}_{s-}^{\pi}, G_{\pi}\left(s, \tilde{X}_{s-}^{\pi}, u\right), z\right)\right) \circ \gamma_{k}\left(s, \tilde{X}_{s-}^{\pi}, G_{\pi}\left(s, \tilde{X}_{s-}^{\pi}, u\right), z\right) \widetilde{N}_{k}(d s, d z, d u)
$$

for some $\alpha_{s} \in[0,1]$. For $s \in\left[t, t^{\prime} \wedge \tau_{n}\right],\left|\tilde{X}_{s-}^{\pi}\right| \leq n$. By Assumption $1^{\prime}-(\mathrm{v}),\left|\gamma_{k}\left(s, \tilde{X}_{s-}^{\pi}, G_{\pi}\left(s, \tilde{X}_{s-}^{\pi}, u\right), z\right)\right|$ is bounded for any $|z| \leq 1, s \in\left[t, t^{\prime} \wedge \tau_{n}\right]$ and $u \in[0,1]^{n}$, which further implies the boundedness of $\left|\phi_{x}\left(s, \tilde{X}_{s-}^{\pi}+\alpha_{s} \gamma_{k}\left(s, \tilde{X}_{s-}^{\pi}, G_{\pi}\left(s, \tilde{X}_{s-}^{\pi}, u\right), z\right)\right)\right|$. Now, for each $j=1, \cdots, d$,

$$
\int_{t}^{t^{\prime} \wedge \tau_{n}} e^{-\beta s} \int_{B_{1}} \phi_{x_{j}}\left(s, \tilde{X}_{s-}^{\pi}+\alpha_{s} \gamma_{k}\left(s, \tilde{X}_{s-}^{\pi}, G_{\pi}\left(s, \tilde{X}_{s-}^{\pi}, u\right), z\right)\right) \gamma_{j k}\left(s, \tilde{X}_{s-}^{\pi}, G_{\pi}\left(s, \tilde{X}_{s-}^{\pi}, u\right), z\right) \widetilde{N}_{k}(d s, d z, d u)
$$

is a square-integrable martingale because

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathbb{E}_{t, x}^{\S}\left[\int_{t}^{t^{\prime} \wedge \tau_{n}} e^{-2 \beta s} \int_{B_{1}} \phi_{x_{j}}^{2}\left(s, \tilde{X}_{s-}^{\pi}+\alpha_{s} \gamma_{k}\left(s, \tilde{X}_{s-}^{\pi}, G_{\pi}\left(s, \tilde{X}_{s-}^{\pi}, u\right), z\right)\right) \gamma_{j k}^{2}\left(s, \tilde{X}_{s-}^{\pi}, G_{\pi}\left(s, \tilde{X}_{s-}^{\pi}, u\right), z\right) \nu_{k}(d z) d u d s\right] \\
\leq & C \cdot \mathbb{E}_{t, x}^{\S}\left[\int_{t}^{t^{\prime} \wedge \tau_{n}} \int_{B_{1}} \gamma_{j k}^{2}\left(s, \tilde{X}_{s-}^{\pi}, G_{\pi}\left(s, \tilde{X}_{s-}^{\pi}, u\right), z\right) \nu_{k}(d z) d u d s\right] \\
\leq & C^{\prime} \cdot \mathbb{E}_{t, x}^{\S}\left[\int_{t}^{t^{\prime} \wedge \tau_{n}}\left(1+\left|\tilde{X}_{s-}^{\pi}\right|^{2}\right) d s\right]<\infty
\end{aligned}
$$

where we used Lemma 2 and boundedness of $\left|\tilde{X}_{s-}^{\pi}\right|$ in the above. Thus, (71) is a square-integrable martingale with mean zero.

For (72), we can use the same arguments as in the finite activity case by observing $\int_{|z|>1} \nu_{k}(d z)<$ $\infty$ to show that each of the two processes in (72) is a square-integrable martingale with mean zero.

Combining the results above, setting $t^{\prime}=T$, and taking expectation, we obtain

$$
\mathbb{E}_{t, x}^{\S}\left[e^{-\beta\left(T \wedge \tau_{n}\right)} \phi\left(\tilde{X}_{T \wedge \tau_{n}}^{\pi}\right)\right]-e^{-\beta t} \phi(t, x)=\mathbb{E}_{t, x}^{\S}\left[\int_{t}^{T \wedge \tau_{n}} e^{-\beta s}\left(\mathcal{L}^{\pi} \phi\left(s, \tilde{X}_{s-}^{\pi}\right)-\beta \phi\left(s, \tilde{X}_{s-}^{\pi}\right)\right) d s\right]

\phi(t, x)=\mathbb{E}_{t, x}^{\S}\left[\int_{t}^{T \wedge \tau_{n}} e^{-\beta(s-t)} \int_{\mathcal{A}}\left(r\left(s, \tilde{X}_{s-}^{\pi}, a\right)-\theta \log \pi\left(a \mid s, \tilde{X}_{s-}^{\pi}\right)\right) \pi\left(a \mid s, \tilde{X}_{s-}^{\pi}\right) d a d s\right.
$$

\left.+e^{-\beta\left(T \wedge \tau_{n}-t\right)} \phi\left(\tilde{X}_{T \wedge \tau_{n}}^{\boldsymbol{\pi}}\right)\right]
$$

It follows from Assumption 1-(iv), Definition 1-(iii), and Eq. (23) that the term on the right-hand side of (73) is dominated by $C\left(1+\sup _{t \leq s \leq T}\left|\tilde{X}_{s}^{\boldsymbol{\tau}}\right|^{p}\right)$ for some $p \geq 2$, which has finite expectation from the moment estimate (19). Therefore, sending $n$ to infinity in (73) and applying the dominated convergence theorem, we obtain $\phi(t, x)=J(t, x, \boldsymbol{\pi})$.

Proof of Lemma 5. We first maximize the integral in (24). Applying (Jia and Zhou 2023, Lemma 13), we deduce that $\boldsymbol{\pi}^{*}$ given by (25) is the unique maximizer. Next, we show that $\psi(t, x)$ is the optimal value function.

On one hand, given any admissible stochastic policy $\boldsymbol{\pi} \in \boldsymbol{\Pi}$, from (24) we have

$$
\frac{\partial \psi(t, x)}{\partial t}+\int_{\mathcal{A}}\left\{H\left(t, x, a, \psi_{x}, \psi_{x x}, \psi\right)-\theta \log \boldsymbol{\pi}(a \mid t, x)\right\} \boldsymbol{\pi}(a \mid t, x) d a-\beta \psi(t, x) \leq 0
$$

Using similar arguments as in the proof of Lemma 4, we obtain $J(t, x, \boldsymbol{\pi}) \leq \psi(t, x)$ for any $\boldsymbol{\pi} \in \boldsymbol{\Pi}$. Thus, $J^{*}(t, x) \leq \psi(t, x)$.

On the other hand, Eq. (24) becomes

$$
\frac{\partial \psi(t, x)}{\partial t}+\int_{\mathcal{A}}\left\{H\left(t, x, a, \psi_{x}, \psi_{x x}, \psi\right)-\theta \log \boldsymbol{\pi}^{*}(a)\right\} \boldsymbol{\pi}^{*}(a) d a-\beta \psi(t, x)=0
$$

with $\psi(T, x)=h(x)$. By Lemma 4, we obtain that $J\left(t, x, \boldsymbol{\pi}^{*}\right)=\psi(t, x)$. It follows that $J^{*}(t, x) \geq$ $\psi(t, x)$.

Combining these results, we conclude that $J^{*}(t, x)=\psi(t, x)$ and $\boldsymbol{\pi}^{*}$ is the optimal stochastic policy.

Proof of Theorem 2. Consider part (i). Applying Itô's formula to the value function of policy $\boldsymbol{\pi}$ over the sample state process defined by (9) and using the definition of $q$-function, we obtain that for $0 \leq t<s \leq T$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& e^{-\beta s} J\left(s, X_{s}^{\boldsymbol{\pi}} ; \boldsymbol{\pi}\right)-e^{-\beta t} J(t, x ; \boldsymbol{\pi})+\int_{t}^{s} e^{-\beta \tau}\left[r\left(\tau, X_{\tau-}^{\boldsymbol{\pi}}, a_{\tau}^{\boldsymbol{\pi}}\right)-\hat{q}\left(\tau, X_{\tau-}^{\boldsymbol{\pi}}, a_{\tau}^{\boldsymbol{\pi}}\right)\right] d \tau \\
& =\int_{t}^{s} e^{-\beta \tau}\left[q\left(\tau, X_{\tau-}^{\boldsymbol{\pi}}, a_{\tau}^{\boldsymbol{\pi}} ; \boldsymbol{\pi}\right)-\hat{q}\left(\tau, X_{\tau-}^{\boldsymbol{\pi}}, a_{\tau}^{\boldsymbol{\tau}}\right)\right] d \tau+\int_{t}^{s} e^{-\beta \tau} J_{x}\left(\tau, X_{\tau-}^{\boldsymbol{\pi}} ; \boldsymbol{\pi}\right) \circ \sigma\left(\tau, X_{\tau-}^{\pi}, a_{\tau}^{\pi}\right) d W_{\tau} \\
& \quad+\sum_{k=1}^{\ell} \int_{t}^{s} e^{-\beta \tau} \int_{\mathbb{R}}\left(J\left(\tau, X_{\tau-}^{\boldsymbol{\pi}}+\gamma_{k}\left(\tau, X_{\tau-}^{\boldsymbol{\pi}}, a_{\tau}^{\boldsymbol{\pi}}, z\right)\right)-J\left(\tau, X_{\tau-}^{\boldsymbol{\pi}} ; \boldsymbol{\pi}\right)\right) \widehat{N}_{k}(d \tau, d z)
\end{aligned}
$$

Suppose $\hat{q}(t, x, a)=q(t, x, a ; \boldsymbol{\pi})$ for all $(t, x, a)$. Hence the first term on the right-hand side of (74) is zero. We verify the following two conditions:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \mathbb{E}_{t, x}^{\S}\left[\int_{t}^{T} e^{-2 \beta \tau}\left|J_{x}\left(\tau, X_{\tau-}^{\boldsymbol{\pi}} ; \boldsymbol{\pi}\right) \circ \sigma\left(\tau, X_{\tau-}^{\pi}, a_{\tau}^{\pi}\right)\right|^{2} d \tau\right]<\infty \\
& \mathbb{E}_{t, x}^{\S}\left[\int_{t}^{T} e^{-2 \beta \tau} \int_{\mathbb{R}}\left|J\left(\tau, X_{\tau-}^{\boldsymbol{\pi}}+\gamma_{k}\left(\tau, X_{\tau-}^{\boldsymbol{\pi}}, a_{\tau}^{\boldsymbol{\pi}}, z\right) ; \boldsymbol{\pi}\right)-J\left(\tau, X_{\tau-}^{\boldsymbol{\pi}} ; \boldsymbol{\pi}\right)\right|^{2} \nu_{k}(d z) d \tau\right]<\infty
\end{aligned}
$$

Eq. (75) follows from Assumption 1-(iii), the polynomial growth of $J_{x}$ in $x$, and the moment estimate (20). For (76), we apply the mean-value theorem and the integral becomes

$$
\int_{t}^{T} e^{-2 \beta \tau} \int_{\mathbb{R}}\left|J_{x}\left(\tau, X_{\tau-}^{\boldsymbol{\pi}}+\alpha_{\tau} \gamma_{k}\left(\tau, X_{\tau-}^{\boldsymbol{\pi}}, a_{\tau}^{\boldsymbol{\pi}}, z\right) ; \boldsymbol{\pi}\right) \circ \gamma_{k}\left(\tau, X_{\tau-}^{\boldsymbol{\pi}}, a_{\tau}^{\boldsymbol{\pi}}, z\right)\right|^{2} \nu_{k}(d z) d \tau
$$

for some $\alpha_{\tau} \in[0,1]$. Using the polynomial growth of $J_{x}$ in $x$, we can bound the integral by

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \int_{t}^{T} e^{-2 \beta \tau} \int_{\mathbb{R}}\left|J_{x}\left(\tau, X_{\tau-}^{\boldsymbol{\pi}}+\alpha_{\tau} \gamma_{k}\left(\tau, X_{\tau-}^{\boldsymbol{\pi}}, a_{\tau}^{\boldsymbol{\pi}}, z\right) ; \boldsymbol{\pi}\right)\right|^{2} \cdot\left|\gamma_{k}\left(\tau, X_{\tau-}^{\boldsymbol{\pi}}, a_{\tau}^{\boldsymbol{\pi}}, z\right)\right|^{2} \nu_{k}(d z) d \tau \\
\leq & C \int_{t}^{T} e^{-2 \beta \tau} \int_{\mathbb{R}}\left(1+\left|X_{\tau-}^{\boldsymbol{\pi}}+\alpha_{\tau} \gamma_{k}\left(\tau, X_{\tau-}^{\boldsymbol{\pi}}, a_{\tau}^{\boldsymbol{\pi}}, z\right)\right|^{p}\right)^{2} \cdot\left|\gamma_{k}\left(\tau, X_{\tau-}^{\boldsymbol{\pi}}, a_{\tau}^{\boldsymbol{\pi}}, z\right)\right|^{2} \nu_{k}(d z) d \tau \\
\leq & C^{\prime} \int_{t}^{T} e^{-2 \beta \tau} \int_{\mathbb{R}}\left(1+\left|X_{\tau-}^{\boldsymbol{\pi}}\right|^{p}+\left|\gamma_{k}\left(\tau, X_{\tau-}^{\boldsymbol{\pi}}, a_{\tau}^{\boldsymbol{\pi}}, z\right)\right|^{p}\right)^{2} \cdot\left|\gamma_{k}\left(\tau, X_{\tau-}^{\boldsymbol{\pi}}, a_{\tau}^{\boldsymbol{\pi}}, z\right)\right|^{2} \nu_{k}(d z) d \tau \\
\leq & C^{\prime} \int_{t}^{T}\left(\left(1+\left|X_{\tau-}^{\boldsymbol{\pi}}\right|^{p}\right)^{2} \int_{\mathbb{R}}\left|\gamma_{k}\left(\tau, X_{\tau-}^{\boldsymbol{\pi}}, a_{\tau}^{\boldsymbol{\pi}}, z\right)\right|^{2} \nu_{k}(d z)\right. \\
& \left.+2\left(1+\left|X_{\tau-}^{\boldsymbol{\pi}}\right|^{p}\right) \int_{\mathbb{R}}\left|\gamma_{k}\left(\tau, X_{\tau-}^{\boldsymbol{\pi}}, a_{\tau}^{\boldsymbol{\pi}}, z\right)\right|^{p+2} \nu_{k}(d z)+\int_{\mathbb{R}}\left|\gamma_{k}\left(\tau, X_{\tau-}^{\boldsymbol{\pi}}, a_{\tau}^{\boldsymbol{\pi}}, z\right)\right|^{2 p+2} \nu_{k}(d z)\right) d \tau
\end{aligned}
$$

Using Assumption 1-(iii) and the moment estimate (20), we obtain (76). It follows that the second and third processes on the right-hand side of (74) are $\left(\left\{\mathcal{G}_{s}\right\}_{s \geq 0}, \overline{\mathbb{P}}\right)$-martingales and thus we have the martingale property of the process given by (26).

Conversely, if (26) is a $\left(\left\{\mathcal{G}_{s}\right\}_{s \geq 0}, \overline{\mathbb{P}}\right)$-martingale, we see from (74) that the process

$$
\int_{t}^{s} e^{-\beta \tau}\left[q\left(\tau, X_{\tau-}^{\boldsymbol{\pi}}, a_{\tau}^{\boldsymbol{\pi}} ; \boldsymbol{\pi}\right)-\hat{q}\left(\tau, X_{\tau-}^{\boldsymbol{\pi}}, a_{\tau}^{\boldsymbol{\pi}}\right)\right] d \tau
$$

is also a $\left(\left\{\mathcal{G}_{s}\right\}_{s \geq 0}, \overline{\mathbb{P}}\right)$-martingale. Furthermore, it has continuous sample paths and finite variation and thus is equal to zero $\overline{\mathbb{P}}$-almost surely. We can then follow the argument in the proof of Theorem 6 in Jia and Zhou (2023) to show that $\hat{q}(t, x, a)=q(t, x, a ; \boldsymbol{\pi})$ for all $(t, x, a)$. There is only one step in their proof that we need to modify due to the presence of jumps.

Specifically, consider the sample state process $X^{\boldsymbol{\pi}}$ starting from some time-state-action $\left(t^{*}, x^{*}, a^{*}\right)$. Fix $\delta>0$ and define

$$
T_{\delta}=\inf \left\{t^{\prime} \geq t^{*}:\left|X_{t^{\prime}}^{\boldsymbol{\pi}}-x^{*}\right|>\delta\right\} \wedge\left(t^{*}+\delta\right)
$$

In the pure diffusion case, Jia and Zhou (2023) uses the continuity of the sample paths of $X^{\boldsymbol{\pi}}$ to argue that $T_{\delta}>t^{*}, \overline{\mathbb{P}}$-almost surely. This result still holds with presence of jumps, because the Lévy processes that drive our controlled state $X^{\boldsymbol{\pi}}$ are stochastic continuous, i.e., the probability of having a jump at the fixed time $t^{*}$ is zero.

To prove parts (ii) and (iii), we can apply the arguments used in proving part (i) together with those arguments from the proof of Theorem 6 in Jia and Zhou (2023). The details are omitted.

Proof of Lemma 6. (1) Consider the function $h^{\prime}(t, S)$ defined by the RHS of (59). Proposition 12.1 in Cont and Tankov (2004) shows that $h^{\prime} \in C^{1,2}\left([0, T) \times \mathbb{R}_{+}\right) \cap C\left([0, T] \times \mathbb{R}_{+}\right)$and it satisfies

the PIDE (55). Furthermore, $h^{\prime}(t, S)$ is Lipschitz continuous in $S$. The Lipschitz continuity of function $\hat{G}$ also implies $\left|\hat{G}\left(\hat{S}_{T}\right)\right| \leq C\left(1+\hat{S}_{T}\right)$ for some constant $C>0$. It follows that

$$
\left|h^{\prime}(t, S)\right| \leq C\left(1+\mathbb{E}^{\mathbb{Q}}\left[\hat{S}_{T} \mid \hat{S}_{t}=S\right]\right) \leq C(1+S)
$$

where we used the martingale property of $\hat{S}$ under $\mathbb{Q}$. The Feynman-Kac Theorem (see Zhu et al. (2015)) implies uniqueness of classical solutions satisfying the linear growth condition.
(2) To study the PIDE (56), we consider the function $g^{\prime}(t, S)$ defined by the RHS of (60). Under the assumption of Lemma 6, the arguments of Proposition 12.1 in Cont and Tankov (2004) can be used to show that $g^{\prime} \in C^{1,2}\left([0, T) \times \mathbb{R}_{+}\right) \cap C\left([0, T] \times \mathbb{R}_{+}\right)$and it satisfies the PIDE (56). The Lipschits continuity of $h(t, S)$ in $S$ implies that $h_{S}(t, S)$ is bounded and $|h(t, S \exp (z))-h(t, S)| \leq$ $C(\exp (z)-1)$. We also have $\mathbb{E}^{\mathbb{P}}\left[\sup _{t \leq s \leq T} \hat{S}_{s}^{2} \mid \hat{S}_{t}=S\right] \leq C\left(1+S^{2}\right)$ (Kunita (2004), Theorem 3.2). Combining these results, we see that $g^{\prime}(t, S)$ shows quadratic growth in $S$. Again the Feynman-Kac Theorem implies uniqueness of classical solutions satisfying the quadratic growth condition.

abstract:
We study continuous-time reinforcement learning (RL) for stochastic control
in which system dynamics are governed by jump-diffusion processes. We formulate
an entropy-regularized exploratory control problem with stochastic policies to
capture the exploration--exploitation balance essential for RL. Unlike the pure
diffusion case initially studied by Wang et al. (2020), the derivation of the
exploratory dynamics under jump-diffusions calls for a careful formulation of
the jump part. Through a theoretical analysis, we find that one can simply use
the same policy evaluation and $q$-learning algorithms in Jia and Zhou (2022a,
2023), originally developed for controlled diffusions, without needing to check
a priori whether the underlying data come from a pure diffusion or a
jump-diffusion. However, we show that the presence of jumps ought to affect
parameterizations of actors and critics in general. We investigate as an
application the mean--variance portfolio selection problem with stock price
modelled as a jump-diffusion, and show that both RL algorithms and
parameterizations are invariant with respect to jumps. Finally, we present a
detailed study on applying the general theory to option hedging.
